accessibilityStatement.title: Accessibility statement for GOV.UK One Login
accessibilityStatement.header: Accessibility statement for GOV.UK One Login

content.paragraph1: GOV.UK One Login is part of the wider GOV.UK website. There’s a separate
content.linkText: accessibility statement for the main GOV.UK website
content.paragraph2: This page only contains information about GOV.UK One Login, available at www.signin.account.gov.uk.

section1.header: Using GOV.UK One Login

paragraph1.text1: GOV.UK One Login is run by the
paragraph1.text2: , part of the Cabinet Office. We want as many people as possible to be able to use GOV.UK One Login. This means you should be able to:

section1.bulletPoint1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
section1.bulletPoint2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
section1.bulletPoint3: navigate most GOV.UK One Login using just a keyboard
section1.bulletPoint4: navigate most of GOV.UK One Login using speech recognition software
section1.bulletPoint5: listen to most of the content in GOV.UK One Login using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
section1.paragraph2: We’ve also made the text in GOV.UK One Login as simple as possible to understand.
section1.paragraph3: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

section2.header: How accessible GOV.UK One Login is
section2.paragraph1: The following parts of GOV.UK One Login are not fully accessible:
section2.bulletPoint1: it’s not possible to stop or change the length of the time-out when you use, sign in to or create a GOV.UK One Login
section2.bulletPoint2: it’s not possible for a screen reader to know when the emails we send are in a language other than English
section2.bulletPoint3: one page reloads automatically after a set time limit, and it’s not possible to stop or delay this
section2.paragraph2: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed or with information about when we plan to fix them.

section3.header: What to do if you have difficulty using GOV.UK One Login
section3.paragraph1: If you have difficulty using GOV.UK One Login,

section4.header: Report accessibility problems with GOV.UK One Login
section4.paragraph1: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of GOV.UK One Login. If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements,

section5.paragraph1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’).
section5.paragraph2: If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
section5.linkText: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)

section6.header: Technical information about GOV.UK One Login’s accessibility
section6.paragraph1: The Government Digital Service is committed to making GOV.UK One Login accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

paragraph2.text1: GOV.UK One Login is partially compliant with the
paragraph2.text2: AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.

section7.paragraph1: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
section7.subHeader: Non compliance with the accessibility regulations
section7.paragraph2: When you create a GOV.UK One Login or sign in, if you do not do anything for 1 hour, the process will stop (time out) or you’ll be signed out. It’s not possible to adjust, extend or turn off the time out. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.2.1 (Timing Adjustable).

section8.header: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
section8.paragraph1: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed, when we expect them to be fixed or when new problems are identified.

section9.paragraph1: This statement was prepared on 4 November 2020. It was last reviewed on 29 June 2022.
section9.paragraph2: GOV.UK One Login was last tested on 13 June 2022. The test was carried out by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC), who produced an accessibility audit report on 17 June 2022. DAC assessed GOV.UK One Login against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines WCAG 2.1.

termsAndConditions.title: GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions
termsAndConditions.header: GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions

paragraph1.text1: These terms and conditions specifically cover GOV.UK One Login. You can use GOV.UK One Login to access and use some government services and features. Pages that are part of GOV.UK One Login have urls containing account.gov.uk. If you are using other parts of GOV.UK you should also read the

paragraph2.text1: GOV.UK One Login is managed by
paragraph2.text2: (GDS) on behalf of the Crown. GDS is part of the Cabinet Office and will be referred to as ‘we’ from now on.

paragraph3.text1: Please read these terms and conditions, the
paragraph3.text3: before using GOV.UK One Login. The privacy notice explains the terms on which we process any personal data we collect from you or that you provide to us. The cookie policy gives information about the cookies we use and how we use them when you use GOV.UK One Login.

section1.paragraph4: By registering for and continuing to use GOV.UK One Login, you agree to these terms and conditions, the privacy notice and cookies policy.
section1.subHeader: Changes to these terms and conditions
section1.paragraph5: We can update these terms, as well as the cookies policy and privacy notice, at any time without notice.
section1.paragraph6: If we change the terms and conditions, we’ll ask you to accept them the next time you sign in to GOV.UK One Login.

section2.paragraph1: You are responsible for making all arrangements for you to access GOV.UK One Login. This includes providing your own device, operating system, browser and internet connection. You should use a device that uses a Windows, OS, iOS or Android operating system. We recommend you use one of the following browsers:
section2.bulletPoint1: The latest version of Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Mozilla Firefox, Samsung Internet or Internet Explorer
section2.paragraph2: We do not guarantee that GOV.UK One Login will always be available, or that access to it will be error free. We will provide a way for you to report problems with GOV.UK One Login.
section2.paragraph3: We may suspend, stop, remove, update or change GOV.UK One Login without notice at any time.

section3.header: Keeping your GOV.UK One Login secure

paragraph1.text1: We have many measures in place to keep your information safe, but as the owner of your GOV.UK One Login, you also have some responsibility for its security. For example you should choose a strong password and ensure you keep it secure. The UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides

section3.paragraph2: If you think that someone knows the username and password to your GOV.UK One Login, you must reset your password as soon as possible.

section4.paragraph1: You will use your GOV.UK One Login to access government services and for no other purpose.
section4.paragraph2: Unless permitted by law or under these terms and conditions, you must:
section4.bulletPoint1: not copy GOV.UK One Login except where copying is incidental to normal use
section4.bulletPoint2: not rent, lease, sub-license, loan, translate, merge, adapt, vary or modify GOV.UK One Login
section4.bulletPoint3: not combine or incorporate GOV.UK One Login with any other programs or services
section4.bulletPoint4: not disassemble, decompile, reverse-engineer or create derivative works based on any part of GOV.UK One Login
section4.bulletPoint5: comply with all technology control or export laws that apply to the technology used by GOV.UK One Login
section4.paragraph3: You must not use GOV.UK One Login:
section4.bulletPoint6: to transmit any material that is insulting or offensive
section4.bulletPoint7: to collect any data or attempt to decipher any transmissions to or from the servers running GOV.UK One Login
section4.bulletPoint8: in a way that could damage, disable, overburden, impair or compromise our systems or security
section4.bulletPoint9: in a way that interferes with other users
section4.bulletPoint10: in any unlawful or fraudulent manner or for any unlawful or fraudulent purpose
section4.bulletPoint11: in a manner that is improper use or inconsistent with these terms and conditions
section4.bulletPoint12: to gain or attempt to gain unauthorised access to the GOV.UK platform, the server on which the GOV.UK platform is stored or any server, computer or database connected to GOV.UK platform, by hacking or other means
section4.bulletPoint13: to transmit, send or upload any data that contains viruses, Trojan horses, worms, spyware or any other harmful programs designed to adversely affect the operation of computer software or hardware
section4.bulletPoint14: in connection with any kind of denial of service attack or for any malicious purpose
section4.bulletPoint15: with someone else’s registered details, unless you have the authority to do so from them
section4.paragraph4: If you breach any of these terms and conditions, we may stop you from accessing your GOV.UK One Login and may take action to enforce these terms and conditions and take other action as appropriate where we have suffered loss. If, by doing any of the above acts, you are also committing a criminal offence, we may report it to the relevant law enforcement authorities. We may cooperate with those authorities by disclosing your identity to them.

paragraph1.text1: You can permanently delete your GOV.UK One Login and the information in it at any time by signing in or
paragraph1.text2: We’ll keep a record of certain information, in line with our
paragraph1.text3: , for audit purposes and to help prevent crime.

section6.paragraph1: We can make changes and improvements to GOV.UK One Login at any time and without notice to:
section6.bulletPoint2: improve the performance of the service
section6.bulletPoint4: reflect changes to the operating system

section7.paragraph1: You can use GOV.UK One Login to access online government services. These services can be managed by GDS, the Cabinet Office or another government department or agency.
section7.paragraph2: Each service will have their own, separate terms and conditions, privacy notices and cookies policies, which apply to the use of that service. You should read these before you use the service.
section7.paragraph3: If a service run by another government department or agency stops being accessible with GOV.UK One Login the service will contact you to tell you what you should do.

section8.paragraph1: GOV.UK One Login is a tool and we have no liability to you for the online government services that you access using GOV.UK One Login. Liability to you rests with the government service provider.
section8.paragraph2: Although we make reasonable efforts to provide, maintain and update a robust GOV.UK One Login service, it is provided ’as is’. We make no express or implied representations, warranties or guarantees that your access to, or use of, GOV.UK One Login will be unbroken or completely secure.
section8.paragraph3: We will not be liable or responsible for any loss or damage caused by a virus, denial of service attack or any other harmful material that may infect your device, equipment, programs, data or other proprietary material due to your use of GOV.UK One Login.
section8.paragraph4: Nothing in these terms and conditions excludes or limits our liability for:
section8.bulletPoint1: death or personal injury as a result of our negligence
section8.bulletPoint3: any other liability which cannot be excluded or limited under English law
section8.bulletPoint4: loss or damage that may come from using GOV.UK One Login that is not caused by our breach of these terms and conditions
section8.bulletPoint5: loss or damage to a device or digital content belonging to you
section8.bulletPoint6: loss or damage arising from an inability to access or use GOV.UK One Login
section8.bulletPoint7: indirect or subsequent losses that were not foreseeable to both you and us when you started using GOV.UK One Login (loss or damages are ‘foreseeable’ when they are an obvious result of our breach of these terms and conditions or if they were considered by you and us when you began using GOV.UK One Login)
section8.bulletPoint8: loss of profits, revenue, contracts, savings, goodwill and wasted expenditure
section8.paragraph6: GDS is not liable for its failure to comply with the terms and conditions due to circumstances which are beyond GDS’ control.
section8.paragraph7: This does not affect any legal rights you may have as a consumer in relation to faulty services or software. Advice about your legal rights is available from your local Citizen’s Advice or Trading Standards Office.
section8.paragraph8: We are not responsible for any links from GOV.UK One Login to websites that are managed by other government departments and agencies, service providers or other organisations. We do not have any control over the content on these websites.
section8.bulletPoint9: the protection of any information you give to these websites
section8.bulletPoint10: any loss or damage that may come from your use of these websites, or any other websites they link to
section8.paragraph10: You agree to release us from any claims or disputes that may come from using these websites.
section8.paragraph11: You should read all terms and conditions, privacy policies and end user licences that relate to these websites before you use them.

section9.header: Making sure these terms and conditions are followed
section9.paragraph1: Each section within these terms and conditions operates separately. If any provision in these terms and conditions is invalid or unenforceable according to applicable law, we will replace it with a valid and enforceable provision that most closely matches the intent of the original. This includes warranty disclaimers and exclusions, and limits of liability. The rest of these terms and conditions will remain in effect.
section9.paragraph2: If we delay in enforcing these terms and conditions, we can still enforce them later. If we do not insist right away that you follow the requirements within these terms and conditions, or we delay in taking steps against you if you break them, this will not prevent us from taking steps against you or prevent your need to follow the requirements at a later date.

section10.paragraph1: The laws of England apply exclusively to these terms and conditions and to all matters relating to use of GOV.UK One Login. Any cause of action arising under or in connection with these terms and conditions or your use of GOV.UK One Login will be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of England.

section11.bulletPoint1: questions about these terms and conditions
section11.bulletPoint2: questions or a complaint about GOV.UK One Login

about.paragraph_one: The GOV.UK One Login system provides a single way to sign in and prove your identity when accessing government services online.

paragraph_two.part_one: GOV.UK One Login is provided by the

about.paragraph_three: Mentions of ‘us‘ and ‘we‘ in this privacy notice refer to GDS.
about.paragraph_four: The Cabinet Office, as GDS’s parent organisation, is the data controller of the personal data you provide when you use GOV.UK One Login. This means that the Cabinet Office is ultimately responsible for the personal data we collect and process on GOV.UK One Login. This includes determining things like what personal data should be collected, from whom and what it will be used for.
about.paragraph_five: Other government departments are responsible for any personal data you provide when you use their online services. For example they may collect data from you either before they redirect you to GOV.UK One Login or after GOV.UK One Login returns you to their service after you’ve completed your authentication or identity checks. This means that they are data controllers for that information and will decide what data to collect from you, why they need that data and how long they keep that data for. Details of this will be in their own privacy notices.

information_we_collect.sub_header: When you authenticate your GOV.UK One Login or prove your identity
information_we_collect.paragraph_one: When you are referred to GOV.UK One Login by an online government service to sign in or prove your identity we will know what service you have come from.
information_we_collect.paragraph_two: The information we then collect from you will depend on:

list.item_one: whether the online government service is using GOV.UK One Login solely to log you in to their system or to prove your identity as well
list.item_two: the evidence and documents you have available to prove your identity
list.item_three: the type of device you use, for example a laptop, tablet or smartphone

information_we_collect.paragraph_three: In all cases, we will create a GOV.UK One Login using your email address. Where you choose to receive authentication codes using text message, we will also collect your phone number. If the online government service is only using GOV.UK One Login to sign you in to their service, we will not collect any further data from you.
information_we_collect.paragraph_four: Where online government services use GOV.UK One Login to prove your identity, we need to conduct identity checks and therefore process additional personal data.

using_id_check_app.header: Using the GOV.UK ID Check app to prove your identity

paragraph_one.part_one: This route uses the GOV.UK ID Check app which is available to smartphone users through the
paragraph_one.part_three: App Stores. It consists of a sequence of checks that are conducted by specialist identity checking service providers on our behalf.

using_id_check_app.sub_header_one: Genuine document, liveness and likeness checks

list_one.item_two: you are a real person (also known as a ‘liveness’ check)
list_one.item_three: you are the same person as in the document photos (also known as a ‘likeness’ check)

using_id_check_app.paragraph_three: We use an identity checking service provider called Iproov and their subcontractors Veriff and Innovalor to conduct these checks. Iproov acts as a data processor with Veriff and Innovalor as sub-processors, which means that they may only process your personal data for the sole purpose of fulfilling our instructions.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_four: We need to check your identity document security features to prove that they are genuine documents.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_five: For driving licences, you will need to take a photo of the front and back of your licence with your phone camera. The app will require permission to access your camera and photos for this.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_six: For e-passports, biometric residence permits and cards, and frontier worker permits the app will read your document information from its near field communication (NFC) chip.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_eight: When Iproov has completed the check, they send us the outcome of the check and your identity document information.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_nine: We do a “liveness” check to prove whether a user is a real person and not anything that might impersonate an individual such as a mannequin, wax figure, 3D mask, picture or deepfake.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_ten: You will need to take a selfie video using your phone camera. The App will require permission to access your camera and videos for this. This check is conducted in real-time which means that neither we nor Iproov store the video.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_eleven: When Iproov has completed the check, they send us the outcome of the check.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_twelve: We do a likeness check to prove that you are the same person as in your identity document photo.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_thirteen: This check uses a still image generated from your selfie video and your identity document photo to measure the unique patterns of your face. This is called facial biometric data. The biometric data from both images is compared to establish whether the user is the actual owner of the identity document.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_fourteen: When Iproov has completed the check, they send us the outcome of the check.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_fifteen: We use an identity checking service provider called Experian to conduct a fraud check to:

list_four.item_one: look for any signs that your identity has been stolen or misused
list_four.item_two: check whether there is a record of you existing over time

paragraph_sixteen.part_one: They do so as an independent data controller in accordance with their

using_id_check_app.paragraph_seventeen: When you have completed the checks above using the App, you will be returned to the GOV.UK One Login website where we will collect your name, date of birth and address. We send these to Experian so they can conduct a counter fraud check.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_eighteen: When Experian has completed the check, they send us a fraud score, plus details of any associated fraudulent activity.
using_id_check_app.paragraph_nineteen: This fraud check will not affect your credit score, as it is a ‘soft search’. An entry about it will be added to your credit record, but it will only be visible to you. Other organisations that use Experian to run their own credit checks will not be able to see it.

using_web_to_prove_identity.header: Using your web browser to prove your identity
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_one: This route consists of 3 separate identity checks.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_two: We check your passport or driving licence details are genuine using the authoritative datasets held, respectively, by HM Passport Office (HMPO) or the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) in Great Britain or the Driver and Vehicle Agency in Northern Ireland (DVA (NI)). You will need to provide your driving licence or passport details which we then send to HMPO, DVLA or DVA (NI) to validate against their records.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_three: When HMPO, DVLA or DVA (NI) have completed their checks, they send us confirmation as to whether the data matches or not and if not, the reason why it didn’t match.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_four: HMPO, DVLA and DVA (NI) do so as independent data controllers in accordance with their privacy notices.

paragraph_five.part_one: We conduct a Knowledge Based Verification (KBV) check, or security questions, using questions about your credit or financial history that only you should know the answer to. This check is conducted by Experian as an independent data controller in accordance with their

using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_six: For this check we use your name, date of birth and address to retrieve relevant questions from Experian. We collect your answers and send them to Experian to check that they match the information they already have about you.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_seven: When Experian has completed the check they respond to us with a Pass / Fail outcome.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_eight: GDS does not store or retain the questions or your answers.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_nine: This fraud check will not affect your credit score, as it is a ‘soft search’. An entry about it will be added to your credit record, but it will only be visible to you. Other organisations that use Experian to run their own credit checks will not be able to see it.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_ten: We use an identity checking service provider called Experian to conduct a fraud check to:

list.item_one: look for any signs that your identity has been stolen or misused
list.item_two: check whether there is a record of you existing over time

paragraph_eleven.part_one: They do so as an independent data controller in accordance with their

using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_twelve: When you have completed the checks above, we will collect your name, date of birth and address. We send these to Experian so they can conduct the check.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_thirteen: When Experian has completed the check, they send us a fraud score, plus details of any associated fraudulent activity.
using_web_to_prove_identity.paragraph_fourteen: This fraud check will not affect your credit score, as it is a ‘soft search’. An entry about it will be added to your credit record, but it will only be visible to you. Other organisations that use Experian to run their own credit checks will not be able to see it.

proving_identity_at_post_office.header: Proving your identity at a Post Office
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_one: GOV.UK One Login gives you the option to prove your identity at a Post Office. This route consists of 3 separate identity checks.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_two: We use an identity checking service provider called Experian to conduct on online fraud check to:

list_one.item_one: look for any signs that your identity has been stolen or misused
list_one.item_two: check whether there is a record of you existing over time

paragraph_three.part_one: They do so as an independent data controller in accordance with their

proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_four: We collect your name, date of birth and address and send them to Experian so they can conduct the check.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_five: When Experian has completed the check, they send us a fraud score, plus details of any associated fraudulent activity.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_five_one: This fraud check will not affect your credit score, as it is a ‘soft search’. An entry about it will be added to your credit record, but it will only be visible to you. Other organisations that use Experian to run their own credit checks will not be able to see it.
proving_identity_at_post_office.sub_header_two: Genuine document check and likeness check

list_two.item_two: you are the same person as in the identity document photos (also known as a ‘likeness’ check)

proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_seven: These checks are conducted by the Post Office and their subcontractor Yoti on our behalf. The Post Office acts as a data processor with Yoti as a sub-processor, which means that they may only process your personal data for the sole purpose of fulfilling our instructions.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_eight: We ask you what identity document you would like to use to prove your identity. You can use any of the following identity documents:

list_three.item_six: National identity card from a European Economic Area (EEA) country

list_four.item_one: for your identity document’s expiry date and issuing country
list_four.item_two: to confirm that the address you provided previously matches the address shown on your identity document, for documents that have an address on them.
list_four.item_three: to choose which Post Office branch you would like to attend

proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_ten: We send this information plus your name, address and date of birth to the Post Office before you go to a branch. We also send you an email with a link to download a Post Office In Branch Verification customer letter. This will contain a QR code and instructions about what you will need to do next. You will need to open the link, enter your email address, and download and print the letter and take it with you when you attend the Post Office, or show it on your device.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_eleven: When you attend the Post Office, a member of staff will scan the QR code on your letter and check the identity document you have with you against the details you provided.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_twelve: The Post Office and Yoti will then check your identity document security features to make sure it is a genuine document.

list_five.item_one: For all identity documents, the Post Office will take a photo of the front and back of the document to check the document’s security features, such as holograms, and to read the document information.
list_five.item_two: For UK e-passports, the Post Office will also use a tablet to check your document’s security features and to read your document information from the NFC chip.

proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_thirteen: The Post Office will also take a photo of your face,from which they will measure the unique patterns of your face. This is called facial biometric data. The biometric data from your photo will be compared against the biometric data from the photo on your identity document to check whether you are the actual owner of the identity document.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_fourteen: When the Post Office and Yoti have completed the checks, they send us the result of the check and your identity document information.
proving_identity_at_post_office.paragraph_fifteen: We then use your email address to tell you that the results of your check are available. To see your result and share it with the service you needed to prove your identity for, you will need to sign in to GOV.UK One Login and be redirected to the government service you were using.

technical_information.paragraph_one: We collect technical information as an integral part of providing GOV.UK One Login to you. This includes:

list.item_one: online identifiers, like your Internet Protocol (IP) addresses
list.item_two: technical information about the device you use such as the model, web browser operating system and unique device ID
list.item_three: This data is stored in system audit and security logs for system and security monitoring and technical troubleshooting purposes.

technical_information.paragraph_two: This data is stored in system audit and security logs for system and security monitoring and technical troubleshooting purposes.

when_you_contact_us.header: When you contact us for help or to provide feedback

paragraph_one.part_one: There are a number of ways to contact us if you need help with GOV.UK One Login. They are on the

when_you_contact_us.paragraph_two: If you contact us for help, we will collect:

list.item_one: information about you such as your name, telephone number and email address, and use this information to contact you about your enquiry and to identify your GOV.UK One Login if necessary
list.item_two: the details of your help request
list.item_three: your preferred language (English or Welsh) so we can contact you in that language

when_you_contact_us.paragraph_three: When you contact us do not include any sensitive or financial information about yourself. If you choose to share details about yourself to give extra context for your enquiry, we will store that information in our systems.
when_you_contact_us.paragraph_four: We store recordings of all telephone conversations. We use these for monitoring and detecting fraud, resolving complaints, quality monitoring and training, and improving our service.
when_you_contact_us.paragraph_five: If you contact us through our web form, we collect technical information about your device as outlined in the ‘Technical information‘ section of this notice.
when_you_contact_us.paragraph_six: If you agree to take part in our survey about the help you received, we collect your answers to the questions. These are linked to the record of when you contacted us, which includes information such as your name, email address or telephone number.

if_you_agree_to_analytics.header: If you agree to web / app analytics
if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_one: If you give your consent, we use Google Analytics to collect information about how you use GOV.UK One Login. For example:

list.item_one: information about the pages you use
list.item_two: how long you spend on each page
list.item_three: how you got to GOV.UK One Login
list.item_four: what you click on while you use the service
list.item_five: technical information including IP addresses, the type of device and web browser you use
list.item_six: an indication of your location (such as your city and country) using your anonymised IP address

if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_two: The information collected is classed as personal data because Google Analytics assigns a unique identifier to each visitor. This does not however enable us or Google to determine your real world identity. We will also not combine analytics information with the data you provide when authenticating your GOV.UK One Login or proving your identity or any other data that we may hold in order to determine your real world identity.
if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_three: We also use Firebase Crashlytics to collect information about problems you may experience when you use the GOV.UK ID Check app, such as the app crashing.
if_you_agree_to_analytics.paragraph_four: In both cases, Google acts as our data processor and we do not permit Google to use or share this data for their own purposes.

why_we_need_your_information.paragraph_one: We collect your personal information on GOV.UK One Login to:

list_one.item_one: provide you with a GOV.UK One Login to access online government services

why_we_need_your_information.paragraph_two: We also use your information to:

list_two.item_one: keep your GOV.UK One Login secure (using your email address, phone number, password and system logs)
list_two.item_two: store your proven identity information within GOV.UK One Login to enable you to reuse it
list_two.item_four: provide the government service(s) that you access through GOV.UK One Login with information about the outcome of your identity check
list_two.item_five: provide you with a record of how your GOV.UK One Login has been used, for example, when it was last signed in to and what services it has been used with
list_two.item_six: contact you about any planned interruptions, problems or changes that may affect your GOV.UK One Login (using your email address)
list_two.item_seven: improve the service by understanding how you use it and any problems you experience, for example using Google Analytics, Firebase Crashlytics and the contact centre feedback survey
list_two.item_eight: monitor the rates of successful and unsuccessful identity checking submissions and produce anonymised reports about GOV.UK One Login to help us understand where we can make improvements
list_two.item_nine: help diagnose and fix technical or debugging issues
list_two.item_ten: assist in billing and reconciliation for the third party identity checking services we use
list_two.item_eleven: monitor the system for security threats and system issues, for example outages.

legal_basis.header: Our legal basis for processing your information
legal_basis.paragraph_one: When we process your personal data for security monitoring purposes, the legal basis we rely on is that the processing is necessary for GDS’s legitimate interests. GDS interests in this regard are protecting GOV.UK One Login and its users against security threats.
legal_basis.paragraph_two: We obtain your consent to process your personal data for the following purposes:

list_one.item_one: collecting and analysing information about how you use your GOV.UK One Login using Google Analytics cookies
list_one.item_two: collecting and processing your responses to our survey about the help you received

legal_basis.paragraph_three: Where we rely on consent we will explain as clearly and concisely as possible how your data will be processed so you understand what you are consenting to. If you later change your mind, you can withdraw your consent at any time. How you can do this will depend on what we are processing your data for. For example, you can:

item_one.part_one: withdraw your consent from our use of cookies using the GOV.UK One Login

item_two.part_one: click the unsubscribe link on emails you receive from us, or you can contact

legal_basis.paragraph_four: For all other purposes including the administration of your GOV.UK One Login, proving your identity and enabling you to reuse that proven identity, and fraud monitoring, the legal basis is that it is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or the exercise of our functions as a government department.
legal_basis.paragraph_five: If you prove your identity using the GOV.UK Identity Check app, you will do a likeness check which will involve processing your facial biometric data. Under UK Law, biometric data is classed as special category data and the Cabinet Office is required to have an additional legal basis to process it. The Cabinet Office processes biometric data on the legal basis that the processing is necessary for reasons of substantial public interest. UK Law also requires the Cabinet Office to meet a specific substantial public interest condition from the UK Data Protection Act 2018. The Cabinet Office relies on the following 2 conditions:

list_three.item_one: statutory and government purposes for identity checking (paragraph 6, schedule 1, Data Protection Act 2018)
list_three.item_two: preventing or detecting unlawful acts for fraud detection and prevention (paragraph 10, schedule 1, Data Protection Act 2018)

legal_basis.paragraph_six: We ask that you do not share any sensitive information about yourself when you contact us for help or to give feedback. If you choose to provide such information we process it on the legal basis that the processing is necessary for reasons of substantial public interest. In addition we rely on the statutory and government purposes condition in the Data Protection Act 2018.

who_we_share_with.header: Who we share your information with
who_we_share_with.sub_header_one: Sharing your information with online government services and the departments that run them
who_we_share_with.paragraph_one: When you sign in or prove your identity with GOV.UK One Login, we send the online government service that you are trying to access the following information:

list_one.item_one: the result of your identity check
list_one.item_three: information that enables the other government service to match you against their records, which typically includes your name, date of birth and address

who_we_share_with.paragraph_two: Other government services process the data we share with them as independent data controllers under a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) we have with them. Each online government service will have its own terms and conditions and privacy notice. You should read these as well as the GOV.UK One Login terms and conditions and this privacy notice, so that you understand how your personal information is managed.
who_we_share_with.paragraph_three: Government Gateway is HMRC’s own authentication and identity checking service that enables users to access tax and other services. The GOV.UK ID Check app is integrated into the Government Gateway service, as well as into GOV.UK One Login, and therefore the personal data processing outlined in the relevant sections of this privacy notice applies to Government Gateway users of the app.
who_we_share_with.paragraph_four: Additionally, HMRC conducts their own identity document checks against authoritative government data sources. We therefore share your driving licence and passport information with HMRC to enable them to conduct these checks.
who_we_share_with.paragraph_five: We share the following information from your driving licence with Government Gateway:
who_we_share_with.paragraph_six: We share the following information from your passport with Government Gateway:

list_three.item_six: International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) Issuer code

who_we_share_with.paragraph_seven: HMRC processes this data as an independent data controller under a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) we have with them under and in accordance with their own privacy policies.
who_we_share_with.sub_header_two: Sharing your information to prove your identity
who_we_share_with.paragraph_eight: We engage specialist third party identity service providers to conduct individual identity checks on our behalf. We share your personal information with these service providers to enable them to conduct the checks.

item_one.part_one: His Majesty’s Passport Office (HMPO), as an independent data controller under an MoU, to conduct passport genuine document checks. You can read

item_two.part_one: the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA), as an independent data controller under an MoU, for GB driving licence genuine document checks. You can read

item_three.part_one: the Driver and Vehicle Agency Northern Ireland (DVA NI), as an independent data controller under an MoU, for Northern Irish driving licence genuine document checks. You can read

item_four.part_one: Experian, as an independent data controller subject to a contract with us, for Knowledge-Base Verification (KBV) and fraud checks. You can read

list_four.item_five: iProov, as a data processor with Veriff and Innovalor as its sub-processors, subject to a contract with us, for biometric likeness checks, genuine document checks and liveness checks
list_four.item_six: Post Office, as a data processor with Yoti as its sub-processor, subject to a contract with us, for in-person identity checks

who_we_share_with.paragraph_ten: In all cases we only provide the minimum information needed to perform the checks.
who_we_share_with.sub_header_three: Sharing your information to protect against fraud
who_we_share_with.paragraph_eleven: To protect against crime and fraud, we might sometimes need to share information with:

list_five.item_one: government departments that run the services you access though your GOV.UK One Login
list_five.item_two: other public sector organisations, such as the Home Office
list_five.item_five: data processors who provide relevant monitoring services

who_we_share_with.paragraph_twelve: The information we might share includes:

list_six.item_five: information about the devices being used
list_six.item_six: identity document details, including name and date of birth

who_we_share_with.sub_header_four: Sharing your information with our suppliers
who_we_share_with.paragraph_thirteen: We work with technology suppliers, for example we use an external hosting provider and a contact centre provider. We only give our suppliers access to your information if they need it to provide their service. Our suppliers act as data processors and are subject to contracts with us which restrict them to only processing your personal data for the sole purpose of providing their services in accordance with our instructions.

how_long_we_keep_your_information.header: How long we keep your information
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_one: We store your personal information for no longer than is reasonably necessary and legally justifiable.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_two: We will keep your GOV.UK One Login for as long as you wish to use it although we will delete it if you do not use it for 3 years.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_three: If you choose to delete your GOV.UK One Login, we’ll delete your account and your proven identity information.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_four: We delete your still photo generated from your selfie video, driving licence images and biometric facial data from Iproov’s systems after 30 days.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_five: The in-person identity check stores your data for 11 days to give you enough time to go to the Post Office to complete your identity check.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_six: We will store the information we collect when you contact us for help for one year. This includes call recordings.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_seven: We will keep your feedback data for 2 years.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_eight: We will store information about the actions you take when you use your GOV.UK One Login in system logs for 1 year.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_nine: We also maintain a secure audit trail of all GOV.UK One Login audit events and activity which we retain for 7 years for fraud monitoring purposes.
how_long_we_keep_your_information.paragraph_ten: GDS does not store or retain the:

list_one.item_one: KBV questions we source from credit reference agencies or your answers to those questions
list_one.item_two: selfie video you take as part of proving your identity using the GOV.UK Identity Check app

childrens_privacy_protection.paragraph_one: GOV.UK One Login is not designed for, or intentionally targeted at, children 13 years of age or younger. We do not intentionally collect or maintain information about anyone under the age of 13.

where_information_processed_stored.header: Where your information is processed and stored
where_information_processed_stored.paragraph_one: All personal data processed directly for the administration of your GOV.UK One Login and for identity checking is stored in the UK or in the European Economic Area (EEA). The EEA has been assessed by the UK Government as having adequate legal protections for data privacy in line with those in the UK.
where_information_processed_stored.paragraph_two: Data collected by Google Analytics may be transferred outside the European Economic Area (EEA) for processing and some of our suppliers may provide technical support from outside of the EEA. In both cases, we ensure your information is just as well protected, for example by including extra clauses in our contracts with suppliers.

how_we_protect_your_information.header: How we protect your personal information and keep it secure
how_we_protect_your_information.paragraph_one: We are committed to doing all that we can to keep your information secure. We have set up systems and processes to prevent unauthorised access or disclosure of your information - for example, we use varying levels of encryption. We also make sure that any third parties that we deal with keep all personal information they process on our behalf secure.
how_we_protect_your_information.paragraph_two: As the owner of your GOV.UK One Login, you also have some responsibility for its security. For example, you should:

item_one.part_one: choose a strong password for your GOV.UK One Login and ensure you keep it secure - the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides
item_one.link_text: advice on keeping your online accounts secure

item_two.link_text: contact us immediately if you suspect that your account has been compromised

automated_decision_making.paragraph_one: GOV.UK’s identity checking process is fully automated and therefore the majority of identity checking decisions are based solely on automated processing.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_two: GOV.UK One Login determines what identity checks need to be conducted to prove your identity taking into account the:

list_one.item_one: level of confidence services need in your identity
list_one.item_two: evidence and documents you have available to prove your identity
list_one.item_three: type of device you use, for example a laptop, tablet or smartphone

automated_decision_making.paragraph_three: GOV.UK One Login then directs specialist third party identity service providers to conduct the necessary identity checking. Most of these checks are fully automated without any manual involvement. For the driving licence check conducted using the GOV.UK Identity Check app, if an automated decision cannot be made successfully, a manual checking process is then used.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_four: GOV.UK One Login receives a response from each identity service provider which contains the outcomes of their identity checks and decides whether the outcomes of the completed checks provide the required level of confidence in your identity.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_five: This process is fully automated and may result in users not having their identity proven to the level required by the online government service you are trying to access. If we are not able to confirm your identity we will show you a screen that notifies you of this, provides you with instructions on what you can do next and provides you with a way to contact us.
automated_decision_making.paragraph_six: Individuals or services can ask us to prove that the automated decision has been made correctly and we will generally prove that GOV.UK One Login is functioning as anticipated without error or bias. We may not be able to provide full information about individual identity checking attempts particularly where providing information would interfere with the prevention or detection of fraud or other crime.

paragraph_one.part_one: UK Data Protection Law provides you with a number of rights which you can exercise by contacting the

list_one.item_one: request a copy of your personal information that we hold
list_one.item_two: ask us to change your information if it is wrong or inaccurate
list_one.item_three: ask us to delete your information, although we may not be able to delete your information if there is a legal reason for us to retain it
list_one.item_four: request a restriction on our use of your information. For example where it is wrong or inaccurate and you would like it to be changed before being used again
list_one.item_five: object about how we process your personal data where we process it under the public task or legitimate interests lawful bases
list_one.item_six: withdraw your consent where we process your personal data with your consent

contact_us_or_make_complaint.header: Contact us or make a complaint

list_one.item_one: have a question about anything in this privacy notice
list_one.item_two: think that your personal information has been misused or mishandled
list_one.item_three: want to make a ‘subject access request‘ to find out more about how your personal information is collected and used

contact_us_or_make_complaint.paragraph_two: You can also contact our Data Protection Officer (DPO) who provides independent advice and monitoring of our use of personal information:

information_commissioner.paragraph_one: You can also make a complaint to the Information Commissioner, who is an independent regulator.
information_commissioner.paragraph_two: Making a complaint to the Information Commissioner will not affect your rights.

changes_to_this_notice.paragraph_one: We may change this privacy notice. In that case, the ‘last updated’ date of this document will also change. Any changes to this privacy notice will apply to you and your information immediately.
changes_to_this_notice.paragraph_two: If these changes affect how your personal information is processed, GDS will let you know.

section1.paragraph1: You cannot sign in and you cannot use your GOV.UK  One Login to access government services.

section2.heading: What you can do
section2.paragraph1: Go back to the service you were trying to use. You can look for the service using your search engine or find it from the GOV.UK  homepage.
